text: hi and welcome to an overview of quickly
deploying an Amazon connect call center
my name is Dustin Harris I'm an AWS
Solutions architect working with public
sector organizations and helping them
improve citizen engagement with AWS
services like connect in this video I'll
review how easy it is to stand up a call
center within Amazon connect and then
step through some of the ways that you
can tailor it to your organization
whether it's a city a county a school
system or really any public facing
entity the first step to standing up a
call center within Amazon connect is to
create a connect instance this acts as
the primary resource for your call
center and it's what we'll be
configuring search for and navigate to
The Connect service page
click add an
instance here we need to decide how we
manage users within connect single sign
on and other Integrations are available
but for now we'll select to store them
within the connect
service let's create a custom URL for
working within our connect
instance next we'll create an admin user
and allow inbound and outbound
calls we'll keep the default storage
options and enable customer
profiles customer profiles lets you
build context and insight around your
citizen engagements so you can further
personalize their experience
later click create instance and we're
almost done we just have to wait for the
instance to finish
building now that our connect instance
is ready all we need to do now is Select
get
started click let's go and then claim a
phone
number this is the number that you'll
direct your inbound calls to so that
they reach the connect
service here you can test our work so
far by calling into the connect instance
that we just created
we'll skip that for now view our claimed
number and then go to the home screen of
connect and that's it we've created a
connect instance and claimed a phone
number for our call center now we can
begin building out the engagement
experience for when someone actually
calls
in a standout feature of connect is the
low code visual builder for creating
engagement
experiences these are called call flows
building out these flows is as easy as
dragging a block onto the canvas and
then connecting some
arrows for example here we can make sure
we begin calls with logging enabled by
searching for set logging behavior and
dragging the block
out we can then continue to build out a
flow to include playing a prompt and
Gathering input from the
caller here we're adding a text to
speech greeting and then prompting for
which department the caller would
like in our greeting we can Surface some
message of the day information or just
some common information like office
closures we can then prompt the caller
for which department they're looking for
and let them select from a
list or instead of listing options you
could also create a chatbot to interact
with the caller and listen for specific
words leveraging our chatbot
functionality for automating some of
this is a great way to reduce the amount
of time a live agent has to be engaged
later we could add a block to transfer
the call to the appropriate agent based
on their
choice all of this can easily be
reconfigured and expanded as your use
case
grows another very common request is to
place a chat widget on to a website for
citizens to interact with because
connect is Omni Channel supporting email
Voice SMS and chat you can leverage this
same visual Builder to create an
interactive chat interface for your
website the chat channel is a great
place for implementing an AWS Lex
chatbot as well as live agents it's an
efficient way to gather caller input or
answer frequently asked questions ahead
of needing an actual agent engaged
once the call Flow and any chat Bots are
created it's just a matter of
automatically generating the code and
placing it onto your
site adding the chat widget to your
website is as easy as navigating to the
connect console and copying the widget
script into the code of the web page
where you'd like it to
appear thanks for watching this overview
of Amazon connect please check out the
additional connect resources here for
more information
